posts.cooked:
Signal for Android has yesterday exceeded the 10 million installs mark on Google Play alone. Congratulations.

Does someone know how does Google count this installs? If user installs an app, there is probably 1 added to the total sum of installs. But what happens if user uninstalls? Is 1 reduced from total sum?

link_counts.title: Mark Zuckerberg: "A Privacy-Focused Vision for Social Networking"

posts.name: Brownstic
posts.cooked:
From what i know, Google doesn’t deduct an install from a user uninstalling the app. Those uninstall stats are separate and only visible to the developer.
Anyway congratulations to Signal App!

@brownstic, you are most probably correct. I see on Google Play web page there are “installs”, but on Google Play store app on Android there are “downloads” in both cases there is 10 million.

We actually do not know how many users Signal really has. This is probably in domain of OWS and I don’t think they will reveal number of users. This is also difficult to measure. What are Signal users? Daily users? Weekly users? Monthly users?

posts.name: Johanw666

Why does it have to be measured so precise? Is a select count(*) from user not more than enough information? Who really cares if there are 10M or 11M active users? The datatransfer through the server is important to know of course to allow for proper server capacity expansion but besides that?

Edit: the PR is closed but not merged, so I assume it was rejected. And I can’t find any discussion, although there were 37 according to Github. And one explicitly deleted comment.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
Meteor0id:

For those wondering why Signal is not offered though the Play Store alternative F-Droid

It is offered on OWS own website: Signal >> Signal Android APK, and otherwise you can always download it from Google Play without an account with a tool like Yalp GitHub - yeriomin/YalpStore: Download apks from Google Play Store . Having had some experience with F-Droid while following Silence development I can imagine OWS doesn’t like it so much: they are slooooow to update and with Silence they can’t even separate beta and release versions which got lost of peoples installations messed up due to buggy betas.

posts.cooked:
johanw666:

Having had some experience with F-Droid while following Silence development I can imagine OWS doesn’t like it so much: they are slooooow to update

I am a big fan of F-Droid, but I can confirm that this is a big problem there. One or two months ago there was in incident where an app needed a very urgent patch, but it took over a week to bring the patched version online.

Moxie exlained few years ago why there is no Singal F-droid version: We don’t distribute our apps on f-droid because we feel it’s insecure, and because it doesn’t provide the features we need to develop stable and secure software […]

posts.name: Harold Finch
posts.cooked:
Hello in this blog there are a lot of new brand user. Do you know haw many signal users??
More than 10 millions?

Harold:

Do you know haw many signal users??
More than 10 millions?

It is probably above one million, but probably not above 10 million. The number-of-installs, just means, how many times somebody downloaded the APK.

  • people might download multiple times, if they have trouble installing it
  • people might download it multiple time, if they switch to a new device
  • people might download it multiple times if they have a work-cell and a personal-cell
  • people might download, use it awhile, and then get tired of it and uninstall
  • a third person might download it, use it awhile, then mute all notification and stop using it, but never uninstall

So the 10M number is an upper-bound for playStore people. You have to add all the signal4ios downloads, and all the Signal >> Signal Android APK sideloads. (You do not have to add signal4desktop… because that can only be installed by somebody who is already using signal4smartphone.)

Shortcut to switch between chats

Some metrics were recently added to signal-server that tries to get anonymized numbers of how many endusers are active in the past day/week/month/year type thing. I dunno whether Signal Foundation collects any telemetry-info on the number of people actively using various operating-system-versions of signal4desktop (they do have distinct “download-links” for each of those however so they can probably get a reasonable estimate).

So there are some folks that know, about how many active users of signal-server there are, during any given month. No stats publshed in public yet that I’m aware of though

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
5_c_d:

and all the Signal >> Signal Android APK sideloads

I assume the number of self built installs is close to negligible compared to the other numbers.

posts.name: Rafi
posts.cooked: Doing a crowd funded promotion for signal might be possible. Imagine the users it will pull into signal.

johanw666:

close to negligible

I’m not so sure. There are two kinds of folks which don’t download from playStore or iTunes…

  • people that are sideloading-without-compiling onto android or a variant thereof (LineageOS / Replicant / TheOsFormerlyKnownAsCopperhead / etc), from Signal >> Signal Android APK … this is possible and only requires enabling a few settings in stock android, too, but is usually pointless there unless a firewall is blocking google servers (any smartphone without playServices / googleFramework / FCM-fka-GCM, though, needs the sideload flavor or hand-compilation).

  • people that are hand-compiling (rare), or downloading unofficial hand-compiled clients (very rare) from those earlier people

Both kinds of groups tend to be exactly the sort of folks who are security-conscious and privacy-conscious and … to put it gently … pretty deep into the spectrum of “enthusiastic about strong crypto”. People that download from playStore and iTunes, are far more numerous, yes. We don’t have numbers there, but just from the number of playStore reviews, there are hundreds of thousands of them who not merely downloaded it but reviewed it.

Whatsapp has 83M reviews and 1B+ endusers, aka tenfold (or maybe even twentyfold) more users than reviewers. Signalapp has 284K reviews almost, which if the same ratio held would indicate roughly 3M signal4playStore endusers, possibly as high as 5M. But I don’t think the ratio is the same, because the network-effect on whatsapp (the gravitational pull of “everybody else is doing it” basically) is very strong for whatsapp, and not that strong yet for signalapp. If the network-effect is only a third as strong for signalapp, that would indicate roughly 1M signal4playStore endusers.

But people who are downloading the quasi-official Signal >> Signal Android APK so they can sideload onto LineageOS … well, we don’t have public counts of those downloads (although OWS does), but at one point back in the day I saw some credible statistics that CyanogenMod was passing WindowsPhone as the third-most-popular-smartphone-OS. During the federation-attempt of 2014-era by OWS, they were estimating as many as 10M active cyanogenMod endusers. Dunno if that value has declined or not, since then… but I very strongly suspect that people willing to flash their own ROMs, are going to be statistically several orders of magnitude less likely to uninstall signalapp, than people who just clicked it in playStore one day.

When you look at some of the comment-counts and especially the +1 reaction-counts on the github bugs over on signal4desktop, there are seemingly a much higher percentage of linux-on-the-desktop endusers commenting, than other folks. It is github, so maybe that is just a venue-related selection bias. But I somewhat-strongly (not as much as my hunch about sideloading though) suspect that folks willing to run linux-on-the-desktop, will also have a higher retention-rate than normal.

In short, if in some hypothetical month of new endusers, you have 999 Carl-clones with signal4itunes and signal4osx, 999 Dave-clones with signal4playStore and signal4winSeven, and 999 Alice-clones with signal4lineage and signal4linux… three months later you might have lost 50% of the iUsers, 75% of the gUsers, and 25% of the libreUsers. “Wild” guesstimates here, obviously. But if you apply those wild guesstimates numbers to ~5M itunes folks, ~10M playStore folks, and ~1M sideloaders & handCompilers over the years (wild-guesstimate download-counts), that would leave your with an active userbase of 2M signal4itunes rounding down, 3M signal4playStore rounding up, and 0.75M “other”… aka 35%itunes 50%playStore 10%neither roughly.

These are, as should be clear by now, mostly just guessing. If there have been fewer than a million sideloads, or if they did not have the 75% retention rate, or if there were more itunes than my “wild” guesstimate (but do note that there are 150k itunes reviews… whatsapp is only ~30x higher in review-count… whereas on playStore whatsapp is ~300x higher)… and so on. Any goofs in the guesstimates, and ALL the nums get thrown off-kilter – garbage in, garbage out. So take this handwaving and making-it-up-as-we-go-along “statistics” up above, with a few pounds of salt.

But I suspect, based primarily on wild guesses and handwaving but also a bit of logic tossed into the mix, that in terms of raw user-count, signal4sideload is a non-negligible percentage of the active userbase, maybe even a double-digit percentage. And I know from anecdata, that in terms of driving adoption-rates, it is the enthusiasts that are batting above their weight when it comes to recruiting new folks to install signalapp, new groups to standardize on signalapp for their groupchats, and so on. Not to mention filing github bug-reports, making feature-requests, and that sort of thing.

Rafi993:

crowd funded promotion for signal might be possible

I would agree… it would be a bit tricky to get it done just right, though.

what would be the goal, of the crowdfunding campaign?

Typically, when small project run crowdfunding, they need money to pay for developer-time. Signal Foundation has money already though, a pretty hefty endowment. They are still looking to hire more people, even. So on that aspect, the normal crowdfunding goal, seems to be short-circuited.

There used to be a bithub project, where if you wrote a code-contribution that got accepted into the main repo as a pull-request, you were given a nominal amount of BTC in return, but this was removed at some point (without much fanfare), as not being quite effective enough for the intended purpose. So crowdfunding as a way to attract volunteer developers, also would be hard to jumpstart.

We could run a crowdfunding “crypto challenge” like the ones Telegram does, but those are generally a sham and would not improve signalapp’s reputation… though if we were to do something legit, it might just be made to work: “Crowdfunding campaign, raise USD$500k to try and draft Daniel J Bernstein into auditing whatever portion(s) of the signalapp codebase he wishes during as many hours as he wishes to devote, in return for the entire amount raised, less expenses paid to the Signal Foundation’s payment-processing subcontractors” for instance, could work. Though we might end up giving DJB 500k bucks for a couple hours of work. Which would likely be well worth it, in my book :-) but not all the crowdfunding contributors would agree with me!

There could also be other types of crowdfunding-objectives, besides more hours from paid devs (they are already working as many hours as they can methinks), more hours from volunteer devs (that is not currently a viable crowdfunding objective methinks), and more security-audits from respected cryptographers (this one could work but would need to be done very carefully).

We could also have a kind of reverse-psychology crowdfunding campaign… if we paid DJB that money to eviscerate the Telegram security, or Facebook secret groups / secret chats, or something… THAT might help. “Signal Foundation pays famous cryptographer to badmouth their competition” might not be the best vibe to shoot for, but I guarantee it would increase the number of people installing signalapp ;-)

Are there other kinds of crowdfunding goals? We could just run crowdfunding for the sake of crowdfunding, I guess…

  • Donate five dollars to signal.org and then you can download the app – or hey, teach them a lesson and just download it for free without paying five dollars… they give it away – but will you feel as much satisfaction getting your privacy back, if you get it back without paying a cent? Well, up to you, but please download today ;-)

That would basically be an advertising campaign for signalapp… and if it raked in some donations, well, nothing wrong with a bit more moolah. Right now though, signalapp is mostly growing organically, based on word-of-mouth. This is often the best way to do it, if you can afford to. People brought onboard by an advertising-campaign, no matter how clever and awesome that advertising-campaign might be, will never have the same kind of retention-rate as people that made up their own minds to try (especially people that were encouraged to try by friends they already trust).

If you start advertising, you take two things away: the made-up-their-own-minds bit (to some degree), AND the friend-who-recommended-it-bit. Usually if somebody installs a new app and runs into a snag, at some point whilst getting a feel for it, they will ask their friend for a hint. But if they installed because of an advertising-campaign, they won’t bother to register a github or signalusers login and seek assistance… too much hassle, just uninstall.

posts.name: Xinping Xi
posts.cooked: Smart people probably downloaded Signal on Google Play to try it out, only to then install the .apk directly downloaded from the official Signal website.

Although that is a common belief among message board nerds like us who maybe want to feel superior to others or something, it’s not actually a recommendation you will hear from software security people who work with at-risk targets in the field.

posts.name: Johanw666
posts.cooked:
That depends entirely on your threat model. If that only includes criminal hachers out for profit then they are probably right, the chance that those breach the google play store defenses are not so high.

However, in Signal’s case, state actors might come into the picture, also the US government, and the chance that they would cooperate with Google to try sending backdoored versions to people vs the chance that they could force Sigal into doing that needs to be considered, especially when you are a person of interest. That discussion might lead to a different risk estimation.
